questions.question: Network security includes confidentiality, authentication, and message integrity.
Confidentiality means only the sender should understand the message.
In network security, Alice and Bob represent trusted parties, Trudy represents an intruder.
Eavesdropping is when an attacker actively inserts messages into a connection.
Spoofing is faking the source address in a packet.
Symmetric key cryptography uses two different keys for encryption and decryption.
Public key cryptography requires both parties to share a secret key.
A digital signature can only be created by the sender using their public key.
SSL stands for Secure Sockets Layer.
SSL provides confidentiality, integrity, and authentication.
TLS is an older version of SSL.
A firewall blocks all incoming and outgoing traffic by default.
Firewalls can prevent SYN flooding attacks.
Stateless packet filters remember previous packets in a connection.
An application-level gateway is also called a proxy.
Network security goals do not include availability.
Hijacking is a type of denial of service attack.
Symmetric cryptography is generally faster than public key cryptography.
Digital signatures provide non-repudiation.
SSL uses only symmetric encryption.
Firewalls are only hardware devices.
A DMZ is a type of firewall.
Authentication ensures the message is not altered.
Message integrity protects against message modification.
Public key cryptography solves the key distribution problem.
SSL handshake is used to exchange certificates and establish keys.
All firewalls support user authentication.
A circuit-level gateway works at the transport layer.
IPsec operates at the application layer.
Wireless LANs do not require security measures.
DNS servers never require security.
Trudy is a trusted friend of Alice and Bob.
Symmetric key algorithms include AES and DES.
Public key algorithms include RSA and Diffie-Hellman.
Firewalls can block malware and viruses.
An IDS is the same as a firewall.
Network security is only important for online banking.
Encryption alone provides authentication.
SSL uses cipher suites negotiated between client and server.
A personal firewall protects only servers, not desktops.
